She was the mother of five daughters, and she had a strong desire to see them all married and settled, but her methods of achieving this goal were often misguided and sometimes comical. Y en cuanto a mi carácter, puedo decir que soy leal a mis amigos y a mi familia, y que siempre trato de hacer lo que creo que es justo. Pero, como dije, soy intransigente, y no siempre me gusta ceder. Me gusta tener razón, y me gusta que se me escuche. Pero, al mismo tiempo, no me gusta ser un tirano, y no me gusta imponer mi voluntad sobre los demás. Creo que hay un equilibrio entre ser fuerte y ser débil, y trato de encontrar ese equilibrio en mi vida.

en_second_half: into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. es_results_raw: la expresión «locamente enamorada». ¿Qué significa exactamente? ¿Es un estado de ánimo pasajero o una condición permanente? ¿Es un sentimiento intenso o una emoción superficial? La verdad es que no lo sé, y me parece que nadie lo sabe. Quizá sea por eso que nos gusta tanto usar esas palabras, porque nos permiten evadir definir lo que sentimos, porque nos permiten mantener una ambigüedad cómoda. Pero, en realidad, ¿qué significa estar locamente enamorado? ¿Es un estado de éxtasis, de felicidad absoluta, o es un estado de confusión, de incertidumbre? ¿O es algo más complejo, algo que no podemos definir con palabras? Me parece que la respuesta es que no lo sabemos, y que quizá sea mejor así.

en_results_raw: is a most interesting young man, and if he were thus circumstanced as to make a suitable match for you, I should be disposed to think of him with the highest approval. But you must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all know it. I have frequently observed your conduct in the family, and I must say, that I have been highly pleased with your good sense, and prudent behaviour. You have a disposition, which will ever be valued and respected, wherever you are; and I dare say, that you will never throw yourself away, merely to gratify a fancy, which may be only a fancy. I am not afraid of your falling in love, without your being aware of it, and I should be the last person to encourage you in an attachment, which could only end in disappointment and misery to yourself. I only wish to put you on your guard, and to prevent your being imposed upon by any one, who might seek to take advantage of your youth, and inexperience. You are too young, and too artless, to be aware of the designs, which may be formed against you; and I wish to caution you, to be careful, and to be upon your guard, against any one, who may seek to impose upon you.

en_results_raw: of saying, and his countenance was as serene as ever. He listened to the various remarks of his family with his usual calm attention, and his only reply was an occasional "yes" or "no", uttered in his usual measured tone. His daughters, who had been so anxious to see him, and had expected to find him in a state of great agitation, were surprised to find him so calm and composed. They had expected to see him pacing up and down the room, and gesticulating wildly, as he often did when he was excited, but instead, he sat quietly in his arm-chair, with his hands folded together, and a look of perfect tranquility on his face. His wife, who had been watching him with great anxiety, was relieved to see him so calm, and she endeavored to follow his example, and to appear as composed as he was. But it was evident that she was making a great effort to do so, and that she was deeply anxious about something. Her daughters, who were watching her, could see the anxiety in her eyes, and they knew that she was hiding something from them.

en_results: what had passed, he replied, "I am not going to apologize for my conduct, nor do I see any occasion for it; I have done nothing but what I thought
en_results_raw: what had passed, he replied, "I am not going to apologize for my conduct, nor do I see any occasion for it; I have done nothing but what I thought was right, and I will not be dictated to by any one, not even by you, my dear sister." Elizabeth was taken aback by his tone, and felt a strong inclination to retort, but she restrained herself, and merely observed, "I am sorry to hear you say so, brother; I had hoped you would have seen the impropriety of your behavior, and have been willing to make some amends." Mr. Darcy's countenance darkened, and he replied, "I do not see what there is to make amends for; I have done nothing to apologize for, and I will not be lectured by you, or any one else." Elizabeth felt her anger rising, but she kept her temper, and merely said, "I am sorry to see you in this mood, brother; I had hoped we could have had a pleasant conversation, but it seems that is not to be." Mr. Darcy did not reply, but turned away, and began to walk up and down the room, leaving Elizabeth to her own thoughts.
